indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) performance benchmarks achieved within set timelines. 2. Independent National Electoral Commission’s level of information sharing with stakeholder.

baseline.comment: 1. Partially - the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) launched its Strategic Programme of Action 2012-2016 with performance benchmarks in June 2013 2. Partially - During the previous electoral cycles, there were no deliberate efforts to share the observation reports beyond the press conference and the lodgment of the reports with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC).

target.comment: Project implementation started in January 2015

actual.comment: Project implementation started in January 2015

target.comment: 1. Conduct extensive voter education campaigns with a focus on youth, women and peaceful elections covering all the states of the Federation 2. Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) to set up and run an Election Management System for effective and efficient operation and coordination of crucial aspects of election administration and management for the 2015 general elections. 3. Build capacity of the Election Petition Tribunals developed with a view to fast- track adjudication of election petitions and address issues of inconsistent judgements.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved: Comprehensive voter education campaigns were delivered in all the 774 Local Government Areas of the Federation through both traditional and nontraditional mechanisms which contributed to increased voter turnout and reduced invalid votes. 2. Partially Achieved: INEC significantly improved on the 2015 electoral process with the automation of many electoral processes, including the deployment and retrieval of electoral materials and personnel and the development of manuals for the efficient operationalization of the appropriate channels of communication and electoral support infrastructure. 3. Achieved: The Election Petition Tribunals had managed to fast- track the election adjudication process with no reported case of election petition lapses and inconsistent judgements

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Processes has been established. 2. Extent to which there is an Improvement in the Democratic Quality of Political Engagement. 3. Extent to which there is an enhancement of the participation by Women, Youth and other marginalized groups 4. Extent to which Channels of Civic Engagement has been strengthened.

baseline.comment: 1. Partially - Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Process yet to be mainstreamed. 2. Partially - Quality of Political Engagement needs to meet the standard set in the 2012-2016 Strategic Programme of Action. 3. Partially - The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) Gender Policy is yet to be developed 4. Partially - Relatively low levels of civic awareness of and engagement with government and elections at local and State levels.

target.comment: 1. Increased communication and cooperation between INEC, political parties, CSOs and key stakeholders to improve public approval of electoral operations and contribute to peaceful elections. 2. Electoral procedures, and voter education materials are appropriate to women, youths and PWDs 3. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) are proactively and constructively engaged in informing and monitoring the electoral process in the lead up to the 2015 elections. 4. Monitor and report the experiences of women during elections to address violence and ensure peaceful elections where women participate freely

actual.comment: 1. The Abuja Accord on peaceful election was signed by key political parties and presidential candidates. 2. Nigeria held its widely acclaimed, free, credible and peaceful elections. 3. The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) instituted the National Interagency Committee on Voter Education and Publicity (NICVEP) which ensured that electoral procedures, and voter education materials were appropriate to women, youths and other marginalized groups. 4. A Women Situation room was established in collaboration with UNWOMEN at the national and 10 state levels which monitored the election and reported incidents of violence against women. The commitments secured from the political parties, youth and the media contributed to the reduced violence incidents while the rapid response mechanism in place addressed issues of violence.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Extent of reduction of atmospheric release of Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) from municipal waste in two states.

baseline.comment: Open source burning of Municipal and Agricultural Waste accounts for an annual emission of 574 g I-TEQ/a in Kano and Anambra States

target.comment: 1. Reduction of emissions in Kano and Anambra States to a level of 350g I-TEQ/a 2. Development of technical by-laws, state & Municipal guidance covering UPOPs reducing in municipal waste management 3. Conduct of municipal waste management training in two pilot states. 4. Conduct of summer internship programme for university students.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - Emissions reduced to 315g I-TEQ/a in 2014 2. Achieved - Technical by-laws, state & Municipal guidance covering UPOPs reducing in municipal waste management developed and adopted by 19 Stakeholders from each Pilot State. 3. Achieved - municipal waste management training conducted in two pilot states. 4. Partially – first part of the summer internship programme for university students done

target.comment: 1. Reduction of emissions to a level of 300g I-TEQ/a 2. Reduction of Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) released from open burning 3. Training of environmental laws enforcement officers from the pilot states on enforcement of environmental regulations on municipal waste management and Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) reduction in Nigeria. 4. Cultivation of 500 ha of farmland without burning 5. Completion of summer internship programme for university students 6. Creation of project e-library

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - Emissions reduced to 274g I-TEQ/a in 2015 2. Achieved - 60 environmental laws enforcement officers from the pilot states and the federal level trained on enforcement of environmental regulations for municipal waste management. 3. Largely achieved - 469 ha of farmland (by 347 local farmers) were cultivated without burning 4. Achieved - summer internship programme for university students completed. 5. Not achieved - project e-library yet to be created.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which regulatory and institutional framework are in place at national level to improve Energy Efficiency. 2. Extent to which monitoring and enforcement are in place at national level to improve Energy Efficiency.

baseline.comment: 1. Lack of clear policy framework regulations and energy efficiency policies to introduce and mandate legal energy efficiency requirements for market transformation. 2. Not adequate – there is limited monitoring and enforcement are in place at national level.

target.comment: 1. Adoption of Energy Efficiency Policy by the Federal Executive Council 2. Procure Energy Efficiency testing equipment for refrigerators. 3. Installation of light testing equipment in the laboratories of Standard Organization of Nigeria (SON) and the National Center for Energy Efficiency and Conservation (NCEEC). 4. Training of technicians from Standard Organization of Nigeria (SON), the National Center for Energy Efficiency and Conservation (NCEEC) and the Energy Commission of Nigeria on the installation and maintenance of Energy Efficiency testing equipment for refrigerators. 5. Produce an Energy Efficiency training manual.

actual.comment: 1. Partially achieved - Draft Energy Efficiency Policy currently under review by the Ministerial Committee in preparation for adoption by the Federal Executive Council 2. Achieved - Energy Efficiency testing equipment for refrigerators procured. 3. Achieved - light testing equipment procured and installed in the laboratories of Standard Organization of Nigeria (SON) and the National Center for Energy Efficiency and Conservation (NCEEC). 4. Achieved - Technicians from Standard Organization of Nigeria (SON), the National Center for Energy Efficiency and Conservation (NCEEC) and the Energy Commission of Nigeria trained in USA on the installation and maintenance of Energy Efficiency testing equipment for refrigerators. 5. Partially achieved – draft Energy Efficiency training manual produced.

target.comment: 1. Review of the draft energy performance standards for air conditioners. 2. Introduced Energy Efficiency standards in 50% of public buildings 3. Relevant policy makers, legislators and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) become aware of Energy Efficiency concepts 4. Conduct Project terminal evaluation.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - energy performance standards for air conditioners. 2. Paretially achieved - Minimum energy performance standard for refrigerators endorsed by the Nigeria National Committee of International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 3. Largely achieved - Over 80% of relevant government agencies have integrated Energy Efficiency into their policy, strategies and activities 4. Achieved - Terminal evaluation conducted

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which biophysical and socio-economic assessment of environmental degradation and climate change have been conducted in Delta State. 2. Extent to which plans for Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have been developed in Delta State public and private sectors. 3. Extent to which Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation interventions have been piloted in communities most vulnerable to climate change impacts. 4. Extent to which best practices for development of Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have been disseminated to national government and to local authorities in other states within the Niger Delta.

baseline.comment: 1. Not adequate – A comprehensive Biophysical and socio-economic assessment of environmental degradation and climate change has not been conducted in Delta State. 2. Not adequate – Plans for Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments is yet to be developed in Delta State public and private sectors. 3. Not adequate – Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation interventions have not been piloted in communities most vulnerable to climate change impacts. 4. Not adequate – best practices for development of Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have not been disseminated to national government and to local authorities in other states within the Niger Delta.

target.comment: 1. Up scaling of climate change adaptation and mitigation projects piloted in the State 2. Conduct three feasibility studies in three prioritised interventions and promotion of private and public investments in Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation interventions in Delta State

actual.comment: 1. Over 3000 persons have been sensitized on climate change, causes, effects, mitigation and adaptation measure 2. 100 household is benefitting from bio-sand water filter in Ashama and Akugbene community 3. Installation of Clay Filtering Machine in Emonu Orogun Community

target.comment: Operationally Closed

actual.comment: Operationally Closed

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Extent to which Government, the O&G industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Extent to which stakeholders support long-term biodiversity management in the Niger Delta by capitalizing and accessing the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government.

baseline.comment: 1. Not adequate – there is weak governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Not adequate - Government, the O&G industry and local communities are yet to build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Not adequate - A Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government does not exist.

target.comment: 1. Develop reliable biodiversity database for the Niger Delta using the Biodiversity Assessment Tool (IBAT) protocol. 2. Survey of the area where the Red Colobus Monkeys are found. 3. Produce Oil and Gas Maps of the Niger Delta Area. 4. 20 Communities demonstrate effective local community engagement in Biodiversity Action Plan (BAP).

actual.comment: 1. Partially achieved - Integrated Biodiversity Assessment Tool (IBAT) is being updated. 2. Achieved - Survey of the area where the Red Colobus Monkey is found has been done 3. Achieved - Updated Oil and Gas Maps produced. 4. Partially achieved - Working Group for the Biodiversity Action Plan (BAP) constituted.

target.comment: 1. Review of Policy document on the Oil and Gas industry. 2. Status of the barrier islands surveyed and documented. 3. Short courses mainstreamed into curriculum of training institutions in the Niger Delta.

actual.comment: 1. Barrier islands surveyed and endangered species documented and mapped out. 2. Short courses developed but yet to be mainstreamed into the curriculum of training institutes in the Niger Delta

result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream biodiversity management priorities into the Niger Delta oil and gas (O&G) sector development policies and operations.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Direct: Improved management of 600 km2) â€œinside the fenceâ€ of O&G operations as measured by adoption of Biodiversity Action Plans for a target number of O&G operations in the Delta.

baseline.comment:
SPDC has carried out BAPs in the following states:
Akwa Ibom (1),
Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve. SPDC has no footprints in this tract, but it still carried out the BAP. the O&G company working in the area, ExxonMobil has not cooperated with SPDC or this project to consider further investments in the Forest Reserve. The situation has further been complicated by new Oil Mineral Licenses (OML) leases in the area.
Bayelsa state
BAP development in Bayelsa has focussed on the Gbaran-Ubie integrated oil and gas project. The following Forest Reserves have been the subject of BAP in bayelsa: a) Apoi Creek Forest Reserve, b) Nun River Forest Reserve, c) Taylor Creek Forest Reserve? (straddling Bayelsa and Rivers states), d) Edumanom, e) Egbedi and f) Ikebiri Forest Reserves. SPDC has not signed off on these recently conducted BAPs.
Rivers state (2)
Upper Orashi Forest Reserve
Taylor Creek Forest Reserve (straddliding)?
?

target.comment: At least 600 km2 of O&G footprint covered by new or revised BAP for O&G operations in ND.

actual.comment: A combined figure of 80608 hectares has been subject of BAP in three states-Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa and Rivers state.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Indirect: Threats to biodiversity linked to O&G are reduced in a spatial area of 46,420 km2 as measured by condition, number or extent of key species and ecosystems in the Niger Delta:
- Area in ND where Niger Delta red colobus monkey is confirmed
- # of hectares of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- # of hectares cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

baseline.comment:
- Area in ND where Niger Delta red colobus monkey is unknown and un-measured.
- Zero hectares of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- Zero hectares cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

target.comment:
- Red colobus monkey is confirmed present in 15,000 hectares by end of project (EoP).
- At least 25,000 ha of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- At least 10,000 ha cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: # of O&G companies and Government agencies utilizing IBAT regularly for Niger Delta biodiversity mainstreaming.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least three O&G companies and 3 Government agencies by end of project.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: # of hectares of community PA/set-aside or other PA gazetted and under biodiversity management in four pilot States of the Niger Delta.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 5,000 hectares by end of project.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Amount of funding committed to the NDBT by EoP.
Presence or absence of operational Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust mechanism and level of funding committed.

baseline.comment:
Zero funding committed.
Does not exist. No funding committed to any mechanism for Delta biodiversity conservation/ mainstreaming

target.comment:
US$3 million committed to the Trust by EoP.
Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust (NDBT) Articles of Incorporation agreed upon by the GoN, O&G companies, and relevant civil society partners and legally approved under Nigeriaâ€™s Companies and Allied Matters Act.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: # of primary laws and policies and regulations improved with biodiversity mainstreaming guidelines, recommendations, and amendments.

baseline.comment: No laws/ policies have biodiversity mainstreamed into them, including the EIA, EGASPIN, PIB, and Oil Spill Response Plan.

target.comment: At least four have biodiversity mainstreamed into their language via adopted guidelines, amendments, or modified language in the laws themselves.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of central O&G policies and guidelines and plans that incorporate biodiversity management checklists, criteria and objectives

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least three by end of project.

actual.comment: Working groups were created and most of the Oil and Gas Policies and guidelines can be said to be 60% completed. Reports are at draft stage. To be concluded by end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improvement in Score of UNDP Capacity Assessment Tool over life of project. (see PRODOC Annex 1)

baseline.comment: 5 out of 48, i.e.

target.comment: Improvement from 5/45 to minimum 10/48.

actual.comment: Assessment not yet carried out as at the time of reporting.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: # of measureable/ tangible improvements in the EIA process for biodiversity mainstreaming.

baseline.comment: EIA has few if any specific biodiversity conservation targets/ objectives.

target.comment:
Biodiversity mainstreamed into EIA process in at least 3 entry points.
(See PRODOC Matrix 1 under the description of output 1.3)

actual.comment: The process of mainstreaming is dependent on the activities being done by the Working Group which is yet to be completed. This would most likely be moved into 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Level of improvement of data available through IBAT decision support tool.

baseline.comment: Info on KBA available through IBAT driven by one taxa (birds).

target.comment: Coverage of taxonomic groups expanded to at least four in total.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Government, the O&G industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in level of corporate investment in biodiversity management.

baseline.comment: TBD at project inception.

target.comment: A 20% increase in corporate investment of O&G companies in biodiversity management will ensure biodiversity safeguarding at O&G extraction sites, pipeline and tanker transportation.

actual.comment: SPDC is maintaining some level of investments in its corporate biodiversity portfolio. But this has dwindled in the last three years. Serious consideation is still given to biodiversity in all development projects. Fall in global oil pices and divestment policies have been implicated in scaling down of biodiversity related activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of O&G companies adopting new BAP for operations.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 3 companies adopt model BAP for their inside the fence operations.

actual.comment: SPDC has adopted BAP as an integral part of its environment policy,.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Stakeholders support long-term biodiversity management in the Niger Delta by capitalizing and accessing the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government at its core.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Presence/absence of NDB Trust operational and funded with a first tranche of US$ 3 million supporting biodiversity conservation in critical ecosystems within the whole of the Niger Delta Region

baseline.comment: No NDBT and minimal funding for biodiversity in general.

target.comment: Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust operational with at least US$3 million in funding supporting biodiversity conservation in critical ecosystems within the whole of the Niger Delta Region

actual.comment: Draft Niger Delta Trust Fund prepared. Prospectus for investors prepared. Consultations with stakeholders to commence.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of community proposed biodiversity conservation projects funded and operational in the four pilot States of the Niger Delta.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment: At least 15 by end of project.

actual.comment: None has been achieved as at the time of reporting. Consultations have began with the relevant authorities in the four focus states for 2016

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which the project’s institutional and technical capacity strengthened in Cross River State (CRS). 2. Level of stakeholder’s support to and engagement in the project. 3. Extent to which a Centre of excellence on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) has been established in Cross River State (CRS). 4. Development of national strategies or action plans

baseline.comment: 1. Not adequate - there is limited institutional and technical capacity strengthened in Cross River State for the project implementation. 2. Not adequate - stakeholder’s awareness and support is low. 3. Not adequate - Cross River State (CRS) is currently not a Centre of excellence on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+ 4. Non-existence of Road map for Nigeria REDD+ Framework and Strategy.

target.comment: 1. Conduct a gap analysis of deforestation Policy, Laws and Regulations in the country and Cross River State. 2. Develop a REDD+ programme strategy for Cross River State. 3. Develop REDD+ information/communication strategy 4. Design of a financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) 5. Preparation of investment plans and enabling programmes for REDD+ 6. Creation and administration of a fund to support community initiatives for REDD+ 7. Strengthen mechanism for community engagement and participation in the project.

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - a gap analysis of deforestation Policy, Laws and Regulations in the country and Cross River State completed. 2. Achieved - REDD+ programme strategy for Cross River State completed. 3. Achieved - REDD+ information/communication strategy completed 4. Partially achieved – a draft produced for the financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) 5. Partially achieved – (draft stage) towards developing investment plans and enabling programmes for REDD+ 6. Partially achieved – (draft stage) towards developing Creation and administration of a fund to support community initiatives for REDD+ 7. Largely achieved – 70 forest dependent communities sensitized and engaged for REDD+ implementation in Cross River State.

target.comment: 1. Established a Centre of excellence & learning on REDD+ in Cross River State 2. Design of a financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) 3. Preparation of investment plans and enabling programme for REDD+ 4. Creation and administration of a fund to support community initiatives for REDD+

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) trained by the project in networking, partnership- building, project planning, implementation and reporting in relation to anti-corruption interventions. 2. Number of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) benefitting from CSO Anti-Corruption Grant scheme.

baseline.comment: 1. 0 – Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) have limited capacity to articulate and aggregate their interest and engage in advocacy on Government’s anti-corruption interventions 2. 0 – No Civil Society Organization (CSO) is currently benefitting from CSO Anti-Corruption Grant scheme.

target.comment: 1. Assess and map current and potential anti-corruption CSO stakeholders. 2. Consult on effective needs-based capacity-building strategy and work-plan to improve their capacities for networking and partnership, project planning, implementation, and reporting on Anti-Corruption

actual.comment: 1. Largely achieved - CSOs Anti-Corruption Programming Capacity Assessment and Baseline Study conducted in September in 17 States in Nigeria. The exercise included a mapping of existing anti-corruption CSOs by theme, geographical area and type of activity, as well as determination of the track record of anti-corruption engagement of these CSOs 2. Largely achieved - Civil Society Advisory Committee was established in February with the purpose of enhancing the project’s partnership with anti-corruption focused CSOs in Nigeria and providing a platform for the main beneficiaries of Outcome 3 of the project (Civil Society Organizations) to offer strategic and substantive guidance on the implementation. Two networks strengthening meetings were facilitated during the reporting period. In addition, Budget Tracking and Monitoring Training Workshop for CSOs was held in June 2014

target.comment: 1. Organize/support two CSO Advisory Committee Meetings 2. Customized project management and thematic anti-corruption trainings for CSOs 3. Provide capacity-building and work towards enabling the grants scheme & design an award grant scheme. 4. Support meetings of 3 anti-corruption networks 5. Production of anti-corruption Outreach materials

actual.comment: 1. Largely achieved- Two meetings of CSO Advisory Committee provided strategic guidance and approved the Workplans for the implementation of the Project. 2. Largely Achieved- CSOs partnership-building Workshops enhanced CSO access to ACAs 3. Largely Achieved- CSOs capacitated to offer top-notch application for, and implementation of Project and Grants. 4. Largely Achieved- CSO Networks articulated and aggregated their Agenda within a coordinated framework with the Presidential Advisory Committee on Anti-Corruption. 5. Largely Achieved- Dissemination of Documentary on Corruption enhanced awareness among CSOs.

indicator.description: Proportion States that have adopted relevant laws in compliance with international standards

baseline.comment: 24 States that have adopted relevant laws in compliance with international standards

target.comment: 1. Conduct Corruption Risk Assessment in three Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) related Ministry, Department and Agencies (MDAs) 2. Implement the recommendations of the Ports Sector Integrity Plan 3. Support strengthening of 3 states public procurement structures to improve accountability and promote public procurement reforms.

actual.comment:
1. Largely achieved - Corruption Risk Assessment conducted in five MDAs (3 federal departments and two in Anambra State. These are: • Ministry of Education - Universal Basic Education Commission (UBEC) • Ministry of Health - National Primary Health Agency (NPHA) • Ministry of Water Resources - Three River Basin Authorities located in (Abeokuta) Ogun, (Calabar) Cross-River & (Minna) Niger States • Anambra State Ministries of Health and Education.
2. Largely achieved - All ports agencies have drafted their anti-corruption policies (ACs) and standard operating procedures (SOPs) with the exception of Nigerian Maritime Administration and Safety Agency (NIMASA) & Port Health Services.
3. Largely achieved – Key activities undertaken to Support strengthening of 3 states public procurement structures are - • Translation of Public procurement guidelines into major local dialect in Niger State • Training of 150 newly elected local government officials and personnel in Anambra to strengthen local procurement knowledge and accountability. • Enhancing of the public complaint management and redress mechanisms in Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Delta States through capacity building for 100 government officials drawn from key relevant ministries

target.comment: 1. Empower youth in Ebonyi State through dynamic and innovative platforms to promote integrity and public accountability. 2. Facilitate the adoption of Integrity Plan on Corruption Risk Assessments in three related Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) at national levels as part of measures to strengthen public accountability mechanisms. 3. Conduct corruption risk assessment in three airports 4. Launch of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and Anti-corruption (ACs) for the port agencies

actual.comment: 1. Partially achieved- Youths in Ebonyi State disseminated key anti-corruption messages through radio programmes. 2. Achieved- Report of CRA in three MDAs strengthened the baseline information on public accountability mechanisms in the public sector. 3. Largely Achieved- Assessment Conducted in the Airport Sector. 4. Largely Achieved- SOPs and AC Policies are being harmonized.

target.comment: 1. Develop of 2nd National Implementation Plan (NIP) for Vision 20:2020 2. Production of Medium Term Development Plans (MTDPs) and M&E framework for two States 3. Extension of Donor Data on DAD Phase 1 and Development of Aid Database in two States 4. Review of key State Statistical Products and Training of Statistical Staff in two States

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - The 2nd NIP for Nigeria's vision 20:2020 was developed. 2. Partially achieved - Two States completed their Medium Term Development Plans (MTDP) M&E framework. 3. Partially achieved - Data Entry in DAD phase one increased by about 40 percent in 2014. 4. Achieved - The State GDP computation was completed in the 6 pilot States.

target.comment: 1. Development of new Medium Term Development Plans (MTDP) in 2 States and Review of MTDP in one State. 2. Completion of GDP computation in 3 States. 3. Convene sub-national aid coordination meeting. 4. Production of 2015 development cooperation report at the national and in 2 States

actual.comment: 1. Review of MTDP was completed in one State, while two State commenced the development of new MTDP 2. GDP computation was complete in one State 3. The 2015 Development Cooperation Report was completed at the National level and in one State 4. The Sub-national Aid Coordination Platform meeting was successfully convened.

indicator.description: 1. Number of entrepreneurship boot camp training has been conducted. 2. Number of youths trained and empowered in key skill areas. 3. Number of physically challenged persons trained on vocational skills for self-employment

baseline.comment: 1. Zero entrepreneurship boot camp training has been conducted. 2. 130 youths so far trained and empowered in key skill areas. 3. 40 physically challenged persons trained on vocational skills for self-employment

target.comment: 1. Conduct entrepreneurship sensitization programme for women owned cooperative Societies 2. Conduct skills acquisition and livelihood empowerment training for youths, women cooperatives and special target groups in 4 States 3. Hold a Youth Entrepreneurship Boot Camps in 3 States

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - Entrepreneurship Sensitization Programme for Women owned cooperative Societies selected from 8 States across the 6 geopolitical zones completed 2. Largely Achieved - Skills Acquisition and livelihood empowerment training for youths, women cooperatives and special target groups in 2 States (Anambra, Delta) and the Federal Capital Territory completed 3. Achieved - Youth Entrepreneurship Boot Camps in 3 States (Gombe, Kogi, Niger) completed in 2014

target.comment: 1. Conduct a Vocational Skills empowerment training for 50 physically challenged persons in one State. 2. Conduct Vocational Training for 1000 Youths and Women in selected trades (carpentry, welding and fitting, tailoring, tye and dying, soap making, baking) 3. Design an Entrepreneurial Monitor for recording of entrepreneurial developments/characteristics of self employed trainees

actual.comment: 1. 40 physically challenged persons benefitted from the vocational training programme and have all commenced self-businesses in shoe making, hairdressing and tailoring. 2. 600 youths and women benefitted in vocational training programmes conducted in Gombe, Kogi and Niger States 3. An Entrepreneurial Monitor has been successfully designed in Niger and Anambra States and pilot tested in Niger State

indicator.description: 1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

baseline.comment: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

target.comment: Project implementation started in 2015

actual.comment: Project implementation started in 2015

target.comment: 1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

actual.comment: 1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - radio sensitization and awareness raising campaigns were conducted in four targeted districts (Kenema, Kailahun, Kono and Koinadugu). This was followed by twelve (12) community sensitizations were conducted in twelve chiefdoms. 3. Partially achieved - 4. Achieved - 12 arms collection centres identified 5. Not achieved - needs assessment of community based micro projects yet to be done

target.comment: 1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. actual.comment: 1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) was updated taking into account the vision of the project. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns conducted for community representatives, local authorities, and religious leaders. Community radios in Guiglo, Man, Danane, Touba and Odienne broadcasted peace messages. 3. Achieved - a training on resource mobilization and project management was conducted for 20 participants (8 women - 12 men). A training session was also organized for 10 governors based at the western part of country’s border in Daloa. 4. Achieved - 5 arms collection centres identified 5. Largely achieved - A Community Needs Assessment has been conducted in all project implementing zones except in San Pedro region.
